Performance

David Hugh-Jones

2022-11-01

Source: vignettes/website-articles/performance.Rmd
performance.Rmd

Speed

The core of santoku is written in C++. It is reasonably fast:


packageVersion("santoku")
#> [1] '0.9.0'
set.seed(27101975)

mb <- bench::mark(
        santoku::chop(rnorm(1e5), -2:2),
        base::cut(rnorm(1e5), -2:2),
        Hmisc::cut2(rnorm(1e5), -2:2),
        min_iterations = 100,
        check = FALSE
      )
mb
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 6
#>   expression                             min   median `itr/sec` mem_alâ€¦Â¹ gc/seâ€¦Â²
#>   <bch:expr>                        <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:by>   <dbl>
#> 1 santoku::chop(rnorm(1e+05), -2:2)   29.7ms   35.2ms      27.2  14.83MB   11.1 
#> 2 base::cut(rnorm(1e+05), -2:2)       16.5ms   21.2ms      43.6   3.49MB    3.79
#> 3 Hmisc::cut2(rnorm(1e+05), -2:2)     45.5ms     55ms      17.3  92.32MB   24.9 
#> # â€¦ with abbreviated variable names Â¹â€‹mem_alloc, Â²â€‹`gc/sec`
autoplot(mb, type = "violin")
#> Loading required namespace: tidyr

Dates 


dates <- sample(as.Date("2000-01-01") + 0:364, 1e5, replace = TRUE)
break_dates <- as.Date("2000-01-01") + c(60, 120, 180)

mb_dates <- bench::mark(
              santoku::chop(dates, break_dates),
              base::cut(dates, break_dates),
              Hmisc::cut2(dates, break_dates),
              min_iterations = 100,
              check = FALSE
            )

mb_dates
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 6
#>   expression                             min   median `itr/sec` mem_alâ€¦Â¹ gc/seâ€¦Â²
#>   <bch:expr>                        <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:by>   <dbl>
#> 1 santoku::chop(dates, break_dates)  19.87ms     24ms      35.8   10.6MB   13.9 
#> 2 base::cut(dates, break_dates)       9.14ms   12.3ms      77.0    3.9MB    6.70
#> 3 Hmisc::cut2(dates, break_dates)     19.2ms   25.8ms      35.1   15.3MB   18.1 
#> # â€¦ with abbreviated variable names Â¹â€‹mem_alloc, Â²â€‹`gc/sec`
autoplot(mb_dates, type = "violin")

Cutting characters (pure R implementation) 


oo <- options(santoku.warn_character = FALSE)


lipsum <- stringi::stri_rand_lipsum(100)

mb_pure_r <- bench::mark(
               santoku::chop(lipsum, letters),
               santoku::chop(seq(1, 26, length = 100), 1:26),
               min_iterations = 100,
               check = FALSE
             )

mb_pure_r
#> # A tibble: 2 Ã— 6
#>   expression                                         min  median itr/sâ€¦Â¹ mem_aâ€¦Â²
#>   <bch:expr>                                    <bch:tm> <bch:t>   <dbl> <bch:b>
#> 1 santoku::chop(lipsum, letters)                   3.2ms  4.87ms    177. 135.4KB
#> 2 santoku::chop(seq(1, 26, length = 100), 1:26)   1.75ms  2.24ms    405.  39.4KB
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: `gc/sec` <dbl>, and abbreviated variable names
#> #   Â¹â€‹`itr/sec`, Â²â€‹mem_alloc

options(oo)
autoplot(mb_pure_r, type = "violin")

Many breaks 


many_breaks <- seq(-2, 2, 0.001)

mb_breaks <- bench::mark(
        santoku::chop(rnorm(1e4), many_breaks),
        base::cut(rnorm(1e4), many_breaks),
        Hmisc::cut2(rnorm(1e4), many_breaks),
        min_iterations = 100,
        check = FALSE
      )

mb_breaks
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 6
#>   expression                                  min median itr/sâ€¦Â¹ mem_aâ€¦Â² gc/seâ€¦Â³
#>   <bch:expr>                               <bch:> <bch:>   <dbl> <bch:b>   <dbl>
#> 1 santoku::chop(rnorm(10000), many_breaks) 43.3ms   46ms    21.0  5.12MB    2.59
#> 2 base::cut(rnorm(10000), many_breaks)     11.8ms 12.6ms    75.0  1.54MB    2.32
#> 3 Hmisc::cut2(rnorm(10000), many_breaks)   34.2ms 38.5ms    25.3   6.2MB    3.78
#> # â€¦ with abbreviated variable names Â¹â€‹`itr/sec`, Â²â€‹mem_alloc, Â³â€‹`gc/sec`
autoplot(mb_breaks, type = "violin")
